drogues de autres substances et au Règlement sur les stupéfiants.";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:357:"Methyldienolone is an anabolic Steroid. It is in the prohibited list of the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA). Anabolic steroids and their derivatives are in Schedule IV of the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act. There is very limited information regarding its chemistry (such as structure and synthesis), biochemistry (such as action), and safety and so on.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76285";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:15:"Methyldienolone";s:5:"title";s:15:"Methyldienolone";s:3:"nid";s:5:"80977";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:80978;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:159:"A non-NHP because it is an anabolic steroid, where anabolic steroids and their derivatives are listed in Schedule IV of the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:225:"Un non PSN parce que stéroide anabolisant, et les stéroides anabolisants et leurs dérivés sont présents à l'Annexe IV de la Loi réglementant certaines drogues de autres substances et au Règlement sur les stupéfiants.";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1739:"Androstenedione is a 19-carbon steroid hormone produced in the adrenal glands and the gonads as an intermediate step in the biochemical pathway. Androstenedione is the common precursor of male and female sex hormones. Some androstenedione is also secreted into the plasma, and may be converted in peripheral tissues to testosterone and estrogens. Androstenedione originates either from the conversion of dehydroepiandrosterone or from 17-hydroxyprogesterone. It is further converted to either testosterone or estrone. In April 2004, the FDA banned the sale of Androsterenedione, citing that the drug poses significant health risks commonly associated with steroids. Because androstenedione is converted in part to estrogens, persons taking this supplement may have estrogenic side-effects. A visible problem could be gynecomastia (formation of breast tissue) in males. Androstenedione is prohibited as an anabolic agent under the World Anti-Doping Code 2007 Prohibited List (in effect 1/1/07) because of its anabolic properties. Anabolic steroids and their derivatives are under Schedule IV of CDSA listing. Androstenedione will not be a NHP,but a CDSA substance. Because it is a chemical precursor of chlorine dioxide, sodium chlorite is also called "stabilized chlorine dioxide". The main application of sodium chlorite is the generation of chlorine dioxide for bleaching and stripping of textiles, pulp, and paper. It is also used for disinfection in a few municipal water treatment plants after conversion to chlorine dioxide. Since sodium chlorite is a synthetic compound (not found in nature), it will not be considered as a NHP, but a drug.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76302";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:15:"Sodium chlorite";s:5:"title";s:15:"Sodium chlorite";s:3:"nid";s:5:"80994";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:80995;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:53:"As per October 13, 2005 decision between TPD and NHPD";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76303";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:55:"Polyethoxypolypropoxypolyethoxyethanol - iodine complex";s:5:"title";s:55:"Polyethoxypolypropoxypolyethoxyethanol - iodine complex";s:3:"nid";s:5:"80995";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:80996;a:13:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:2:"67";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:528:"Polyvinyl alcohol (or PVA) is a synthetically prepared polymer synthesized not by polymerization of the corresponding monomer (its monomer exist only as the tautomeric form, acetaldehyde), but by partial or total hydrolysis of polyvinyl acetate.  This polymer is widely used in industry because of its changing properties depending on the length of the carbon chain, which is also why it is listed in the NHPD acceptable NMIs list.  Since Polyvinyl alcohol is not found in nature, it will be considered as a non-NHP, but a drug.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76304";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:17:"Polyvinyl alcohol";s:5:"title";s:17:"Polyvinyl alcohol";s:3:"nid";s:5:"80996";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:80997;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:213:"Mexoryl or 3,3'-terephthalydene 10,10'-dicamphorsulfonic acid is used to formulate sunscreens and moisturizers. Since Mexoryl is a synthetic product that is not found in nature, it will not be considered as a NHP.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76305";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:8:"Ecamsule";s:5:"title";s:8:"Ecamsule";s:3:"nid";s:5:"80997";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:80998;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:660:"Ammoniated mercury (Mercuric Chloride Ammoniated, Hg(NH2)Cl) is a synthetic drug derived from mercuric salts and ammonia. This drug is available over the counter without a prescription and is used to treat impetigo, psoriasis, minor skin infections, and other skin disorders but the use of such mercurial preparations is generally deprecated. Frequent or prolonged application to large areas or to broken skin or mucous membranes can cause mercury poisoning. Ammoniated mercury is also a potent sensitizer and can produce allergic reactions.  Since ammoniated mercury is a synthetic drug that is not found in nature, it will be considered as a drug, not a NHP.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76306";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:29:"Mercuric chloride, ammoniated";s:5:"title";s:29:"Mercuric chloride, ammoniated";s:3:"nid";s:5:"80998";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:80999;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:6388:"Ipriflavone is a semisynthetic isoflavone prepared synthetically from the soy isoflavone Daidzein [1,2,3]. It is also the isopropyl ether derivative of another naturally occurring isoflavone called 7-Hydroxyisoflavone, a constituent of the flowers of Thespesia populnea [4].  Ipriflavone is used orally in Europe and Japan for the prevention and treatment of osteoporosis, mainly in postmenopausal women [5].  This usage has been supported by many in vivo and in vitro studies (mainly before 2000), both in animal and human models, demonstrating several possible mechanisms of action [6].  For example,  some studies suggested that Ipriflavone inhibits bone resorption and stimulates osteoblast activity in vitro in cell cultures [7,8] and in vivo in experimental models of osteoporosis, such as showing inhibition of bone loss in osteoporotic rats [9].  One of the advantages for using Ipriflavone in the treatment of osteoporosis is its lack of direct estrogenic effect demonstrated by the in vitro investigation of the interaction between Ipriflavone and preosteoclastic cell lines, which showed that it was not mediated by direct interaction with estrogen receptors, but with the interaction of novel receptors coupled to calcium influx [10, 11].  In comparison, naturally occurring isoflavones (e.g. daidzein and genistein) are known to bind to estrogen receptors leading to weak estrogenic and antiestrogenic activities [12].  Ipriflavone is known to be metabolized to 7 metabolites (M1 to M7) mainly in the liver, by oxidation of the isopropyl group and/or hydroxylation of the beta-ring followed by phase II glucuronidation or sulfation (Fig. 1).  Since M1 (7-Hydroxyisoflavone), M2 (Daidzein), M3, and M5 have shown some pharmacological activity related to bone formation and bone resorption [13], the overall pharmacological activity of Ipriflavone is not only the result of Ipriflavone and its naturally occurring metabolites M1 and M2, but also the result of its non-natural metabolites M3 and M5.  For example, an in vitro examination of the osteoblastic effect of ipriflavone and its metabolites showed that Ipriflavone and one of its metabolites stimulated cell proliferation of an osteoblast-cell line, whereas ipriflavone and another metabolite increased alkaline phosphatase activity, while another metabolite enhanced collagen formation [10, 14].  In another study, the plasma concentrations of Ipriflavone and two of its metabolites showed that the concentration of Ipriflavone in plasma (subject receiving 3 x 200 mg daily doses for 48 weeks) was a minor component (in the range of 0.33 uM), that the major metabolite was 7-(1-Carboxy-ethoxy)-isoflavone (M5; 3.46 uM), whereas the dealkylated metabolite (M1; 7-Hydroxyisoflavone) was in the range of 1.44 uM [15]. These results led to a number of conflicting clinical trials testing the efficacy on bone mass and safety of Ipriflavone in various populations; where most studies have shown that Ipriflavone is able to prevent bone loss and increase bone mass in postmenopausal women [6,10].  However, in 2001, a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, 4-year clinical trial designed to investigate the efficacy and safety of Ipriflavone on bone density, biochemical markers of bone turnover, and fracture rate in postmenopausal women with osteoporosis concluded that Ipriflavone does not prevent bone loss or affect biochemical markers of bone metabolism.  Additionnaly, this study found that Ipriflavone induces lymphocytopenia in a significant number of women [16].  These results led to another study on soy protein supplementation, where the results showed that overall consumption of 25g soy protein containing 60mg isoflavones daily for one year does not cause lymphocytopenia [17]. Despite the fact that the safety & efficacy of Ipriflavone is not fully understood, these findings demonstrated that 1) Ipriflavone is not a naturally occurring substance, and 2) Ipriflavone shows a different ADMET (Administration, Distribution, Metabolism, Excretion, and Toxicity) profile than the natrurally occurring substances Daidzein and 7-Hydroxyisoflavone.  Therefore, Ipriflavone will not be considered as an NHP, neither a source of an NHP, but a drug.

Since DMSA is a synthetic product that is not found in nature, it will be considered as a drug, not a NHP.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76308";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:8:"Succimer";s:5:"title";s:8:"Succimer";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81000";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81001;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1064:"We spent sometimes looking for any isohumulones natural sources and it seems that there isn't any. The only way to produce this product is through wort boiling transformations of the humulones which have been studied in great detail. By far the most important chemical conversion overall during the brewing of beer is the thermal isomerization of the alpha-acids or humulones to the iso-alpha-acids or isohumulones via an acyloin-type ring contraction. Each humulone gives rise to two epimeric isohumulones, which are distinguished as cis-isohumulones and trans-isohumulones, depending on the spatial arrangement of the tertiary alcohol function at C(4) and the prenyl side chain at C(5). The terms trans and cis indicate that these groups point to opposite faces and to the same face of the five-membered ring, respectively. Since cis- and trans-isohumulones are neither found naturally nor produced by a normal fermentation process and they are only produced via wort boiling transformation of the humulones, these products will be considered as drugs, not NHPs.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76309";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:11:"Isohumulone";s:5:"title";s:11:"Isohumulone";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81001";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81002;a:13:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:7:"67;2977";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:320:"BHT is a phenolic compound often added to foods to preserve fats or act as an antioxidant. It reacts with oxygen free radicals. It can thus slow down the autoxidation rate of ingredients in a product that can cause changes in the taste or color. NMI.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76310";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:24:"Butylated hydroxytoluene";s:5:"title";s:24:"Butylated réglementaire non applicable aux gaz médicaux";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1255:"Nitric oxide (NO) is a gas. It is highly reactive; that is, it participates in many chemical reactions. NO is synthesized within cells by an enzyme NO synthase (NOS) and the human (and mouse) genome contains 3 different genes encoding NO synthases. All types of NOS produce NO from arginine with the aid of molecular oxygen and NADPH. Nitroglycerine, which is often prescribed to reduce the pain of angina, does so by generating nitric oxide, which relaxes the walls of the coronary arteries and arterioles. NO has been implicated in many plant activities and considered as a weapon against invading pathogens in plants. The popular prescription drug sildenafil citrate (Viagra®) enhance the effects of NO by inhibiting the enzyme that normally breaks down cGMP. Nitrogen monoxide (NO), or Nitric oxide, is a colourless gas discovered during the 1980s to act as a chemical messenger in small quantities within the human body, despite being toxic at higher concentrations and its rapid reaction with oxygen. The medical condition of septic shock is linked to overproduction by the body of nitrogen monoxide. In conclusion, nitric oxide (NO) and nitrogen oxide (NO2) belongs to the same family, both are classified as medical gases and considered as drugs.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76346";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:12:"Nitric oxide";s:5:"title";s:12:"Nitric oxide";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81036";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81037;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:53:"As per October 13, 2005 decision between TPD and NHPD";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76347";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:8:"Cinoxate";s:5:"title";s:8:"Cinoxate";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81037";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81038;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:608:"Phenylephrine is an alpha-adrenergic receptor agonist, mainly used as a decongestant, mydriatic agent (to dilate the pupil) and as a vasopressor (to increase blood pressure). It is also produced by various microorganisms from fermentation and cellular respiration and therefore carbon dioxide is considered as a natural substance. However, NHP Regulations did not intend to capture and regulate medicinal gases such as oxygen and carbon dioxide and therefore these gases will be added to the Schedule 2 of the NHP Regulations to exclude them. Mammals and birds are not able to digest Lactulose so it passes unabsorbed from mouth all the way down to the large intestine, which indicates that it is resistant to hydrolysis by human digestive enzymes. However,  Lactulose is fermented by bifidobacteria, lactobacilli and some other bacteria in the colon to produce mainly organic acids, such as lactic acid and small-chain fatty acids such as lactic, acetic and formic acid, which, by exerting a local osmotic effect in the colon, result in increased fecal bulk and stimulation of peristals. Although the metabolites are naturally occurring carboxylic acids (lactic, acetic and formic), Lactulose is a synthetic drug that is not found in nature and therefore it will be considered as a drug, not a NHP.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76365";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:9:"Lactulose";s:5:"title";s:9:"Lactulose";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81052";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81053;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:53:"As per October 13, 2005 decision between TPD and NHPD";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76366";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:16:"Docusate calcium";s:5:"title";s:16:"Docusate calcium";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81053";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81054;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:212:"Phenoxyethanol is a synthetic product that is not found in nature, it is produced by treatment of phenol with ethylene oxide in basic conditions. non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1640:"Isomalt is a disaccharide alcohol belonging to the group of sugar alcohols or polyols. Isomalt is derived from sucrose in a two-stage chemical process. First, the sucrose is converted to the disaccharide 6-0-alpha-D-glucopyranosyl fructose (isomaltulose)  -  a significantly more stable reducing compound.  The isomaltulose is then enriched with hydrogen under high pressure with the aid of a Raney-Nickel catalyst. Despite the fact that Isomalt can also be made in two-step process including enzyme rearrangement followed by addition of two hydrogens, there is no reference to confirm that Isomalt is produced naturally. NHPD agrees that most polyols are present in nature and for example sugar and xylose derived from corn cobs, almond shells and birch bark have become a source for production of isomalt and xylitol respectively. However, these source materials undergo further chemical changes after isolation from their natural sources: the starch from the cereal undergoes an enzymatic conversion to the proper disaccharides followed by hydrogenation in the presence of Raney-Nickel catalysts to convert the aldehyde and ketone groups into alcohol functions.  As a consequence, the chemical structure is made linear and the chemical stability is improved. It also modifies several physicochemical properties such as solubility, viscosity, hygroscopicity and boiling temperature which all contributes to the differences in behaviour between polyols. Since the chemical and physical properties of the natural sugar is changed completely to produce different product (isomalt), therefore, isomalt will be considered as a drug, not a NHP.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76370";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:9:"Palatinit";s:5:"title";s:9:"Palatinit";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81057";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81058;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:385:"Clotrimazole and its salts (except in preparations for topical and vaginal use) are listed under Schedule F ingredients and therefore they are drugs. However, because this chemical is not found in nature, it will be considered as a drug, not a NHP.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76377";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:16:"Sodium bisulfite";s:5:"title";s:16:"Sodium bisulfite";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81064";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81065;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1473:"Benzoyl peroxide preparations have proven to be effective agents in the treatment of acne. It was found that benzoyl peroxide penetrates the stratum corneum very quickly where it is rapidly degraded to benzoic acid. The mechanism of action of Benzoyl peroxide is not totally understood but its antibacterial activity is presumed that benzoyl peroxide is easily absorbed into pores where it works by interfering with acne bacterial metabolism through oxidation. Little is known about the percutaneous penetration, metabolism, and excretion of Benzoyl peroxide, although it has been shown that Benzoyl peroxide absorbed by the skin is metabolized to benzoic acid and then excreted as benzoate in the urine. Unlike hydrogen peroxide, the first reaction/decomposition that will occur in the utilization of Benzoyl peroxide is the cleavage of the peroxide linkage to produce the stabilized benzyl radical species. This active radical species will act in turn as a strong oxidizing agent in the surrounding media and producing benzoic acid as a side product. Despite the fact that Benzoyl peroxide is a derivative of hydrogen peroxide, it is neither acting in a similar way to hydrogen peroxide nor considered as a source material for hydrogen peroxide. Furthermore, Benzoyl peroxide and benzoyl radical intermediate having different chemical and physical properties than the natural benzoic acid and its salt. Therefore, Benzoyl peroxide will be considered as a drug, not a NHP.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76378";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:16:"Benzoyl peroxide";s:5:"title";s:16:"Benzoyl peroxide";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81065";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81066;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:53:"As per October 13, 2005 decision between TPD and NHPD";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76380";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:8:"Riseptin";s:5:"title";s:8:"Riseptin";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81066";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81067;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:980:"Trichloroacetic acid is an analog of acetic acid which can be prepared by oxidation of chloral hydrate with nitric acid or by chlorination of acetic acid. It is widely used in biochemistry for the precipitation of macromolecules such as proteins, DNA and RNA and as a selective herbicide. It also finds use in the metal, plastics and textile industries and as an analytical reagent. Interestingly, Trichloroacetic acid is a urinary metabolite of trichloroethylene and perchloroethylene. Although available data for trichloroacetic acid are sufficient to demonstrate that food and air are relevant exposure sources in addition to drinking-water, the data are not adequate to quantify the contributions of each source for an overall assessment of exposure. Wider exposure to trichloroacetic acid occurs at microgram-per-litre levels in drinking-water and swimming pools as a result of chlorination or chloramination. Trichloroacetic acid will not be considered as a NHP, but a drug.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76381";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:20:"Trichloroacetic insect repellents. Permethrin is a member of the synthetic chemicals called pyrethroids, which are similar to the naturally occurring Pyrethrins [Pyrethrin I and Pyrethrin II], produced by Chrysanthemum cinerariaefolium and Chrysanthemum coccineum .  However, Permethrin is a synthetically prepared compound, more stable to light, as active as the natural Pyrethrins and with lower mammalian toxicity, where the (1R,trans) and the (1R,cis) isomers are primarily responsible for the insecticidal activity.  For these reasons, Permethrin will be considered as a drug, not Guar galactomannan (or natural guar) is a water-soluble polysaccharide extracted from the seeds of Cyamopsi tetragonoloba, which consists of a linear backbone of beta-1,4 linked mannose units solubilized by alpha-1,6 galactose units side chains.  Because natural guars are known to contained as much as 10-14% insoluble residues, more soluble derivatives, such as hydroxypropyl guar, are used in various commercial applications.  Hydroxypropyl guar is made by treating natural guar with propylene oxide in an alkaline medium, which makes it more soluble in water with less insoluble residues.  Since hydroxypropyl guar is a synthetic product that is not found in nature, it will be considered as a drug, not a NHP.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76430";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:18:"Hydroxypropyl guar";s:5:"title";s:18:"Hydroxypropyl guar";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81116";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81117;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:485:"Ciclesonide is a novel nonhalogenated inhalative glucocorticoid.  Since this chemical is a prodrug, it is converted in the lung to a potent metabolite, which have an affinity for the glucocorticoid receptor 100 times higher than the parent molecule.  Ciclesonide was found to be clinically effective essentially against bronchial asthma.  Since Ciclesonide is synthetically prepared by Altana Pharma Incorporated that is not found in nature, it will be considered as a drug, not a NHP.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76431";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:11:"Ciclesonide";s:5:"title";s:11:"Ciclesonide";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81117";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81118;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1068:"Bismuth Trinitrate Pentahydrate, Bi (NO3)3. 5H2O. Colorless, columnal crystals. Prepared by dissolving bismuth metal, Bi2O3, or (BiO)2CO3 in nitric acid. The nitrate is soluble in strong inorganic acids, glacial acetic acid, and glycerol. It is the starting material for basic bismuth nitrates of composition x Bi2O3 · yN2O5 · z H2O. Bismutum subnitricum, approximate composition 6Bi 2O3· 5N2O5 · 9H2O, was commonly used for medical purposes. Bismuth nitrate (or Bismuth trinitrate, CAS: [10361-44-1]) is a strong oxidizer and can be used as radiogenic agent. Bismuth nitrate is synthetic and not found in nature and will be considered as a drug, not NHP.                                                                                 Ref.:

Despite the fact that Methylene blue is acceptable as a NMI, it is a synthetic product that is not found in nature and therefore it will be considered as a drug, not a NHP.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76433";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:14:"Methylene blue";s:5:"title";s:14:"Methylene blue";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81119";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81120;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:579:"Prednisolone is used as eyedrops or ointments in the reduction of irritation, redness, burning, and swelling of eye inflammation caused by chemicals, heat, radiation, infection, allergy, or other foreign bodies in the eye.  It is also used after eye surgery.  It is known to be the active compound of the oral prodrug Prednisone, converted to Prednisolone in the liver, which is why Prednisolone is considered to be metabolically interconvertible with Prednisone.  Since this product is a synthetic corticosteroid, not found in nature, it will be considered as a drug, not a NHP.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76434";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:12:"Prednisolone";s:5:"title";s:12:"Prednisolone";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81120";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81121;a:13:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:13:"field_its_ids";s:2:"67";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:620:"Ammonium laureth sulfate (or Ammonium lauryl ether sulfate) is a chemical compound used mainly in the cosmetics/personal care industry, as a detergent and surfactant, which is why this compound is listed in the NHPD acceptable NMIs list.  This chemical have similar properties than ammonium lauryl sulfate or sodium lauryl sultate (already classified in the database as a drug), except that Ammonium laureth sulfate, being a slightly larger molecule, do not penetrate the skin and hair as easily.  Since Ammonium laureth sulfate is synthetically prepared, not found in nature, it will be considered as a drug, not a NHP.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76435";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:24:"Ammonium laureth sulfate";s:5:"title";s:24:"Ammonium laureth sulfate";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81121";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81122;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:746:"Tetradecylthioacetic acid (TTA) is a novel sulfur-substituted fatty acid analog, which has been studied in animal models for the treatment of glioma cancers.  TTA has chemical and physical properties almost identical to normal and natural saturated fatty acids, but TTA cannot undergo ß-oxidation, which is the reason why TTA is believed to reduce proliferation of both rat and human glioma cells.  For example, Gerge et al. have demonstrated that the presence of 100 µm TTA reduced the accumulation of DNA by ~45% in rat BT4Cn glioma cells after 8 days of treatment, whereas the control (palmitic acid) had no effect on DNA accumulation.  Since TTA is synthetically prepared and not found in nature, it will be considered as a drug, not a NHP.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76436";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:25:"Tetradecylthioacetic acid";s:5:"title";s:25:"Tetradecylthioacetic acid";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81122";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81123;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:670:"Phenyltrimethicone is an inorganic-organic polymer part of the silicones family, which are polymers consisting of inorganic silicon-oxygen backbone (-Si-O-Si-O-) and an organic side groups, such as methyl, ethyl and phenyl groups.  Since these polymers can be syntesized with different  chain lenghts, side groups and may be crosslinked, they can have different physical properties, which is why silicones can be liquids, gels, rubbers, hard plastics, etc.  Phenyltrimethicone is used principally in the cosmetic industry as an emollient, lubricant agent.  Since Phenyltrimethicone is a synthetic polymer, not found in nature, it will be considered as a drug, not a NHP.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76437";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:19:"Phenyl trimethicone";s:5:"title";s:19:"Phenyl trimethicone";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81123";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81124;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:369:"4-Hydroxy-3,5-diiodophenylacetic acid is a synthetically prepared derivative of the naturally occurring compound 4-Hydroxyphenylacetic acid, which is found in many biological sources such as sweet clover (Melilotus officinalis) and in the seeds of Taraxacum officinale. preparations, shower gels, face cleansers, etc...) derived from a combination of glutamic acid and natural coconut fatty acids.  Since this chemical is not naturally occurring, nor used as a source of glutamic acid and/or coconut oil, it will be considered as a drug; not a NHP.  However, since foaming agent/surfactant/cleansing agent are considered acceptable NMI purposes, Sodium cocoyl glutamate will be considered as an acceptable NMI, provided the necessary evidence, since not currently listed in the NHPD acceptable NMIs list.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76479";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:23:"Sodium cocoyl glutamate";s:5:"title";s:23:"Sodium cocoyl glutamate";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81164";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81165;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:321:"Dasatinib is a novel, orally available, small-molecule multitargeted kinase inhibitor produced by Bristol-Myers Squibb (sold under the trade name Sprycel) targeted to treat patients with chronic myelogenous leukemia. This compound has been associated with the marketing of a dietary supplement containing an amphetamine-like substance that would be undetectable in current sports drug tests, prepared by an Illinois chemist involved in a steroid scandal in the United States. Lenalidomide is a synthetically prepared drug (derivative of Thalidomide, a Schedule F drug), sold under the tradename Revlimid by Celgene; therefore, it is not a naturally occurring substance and consequently, it will be considered as a drug.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76483";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:12:"Lenalidomide";s:5:"title";s:12:"Lenalidomide";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81168";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81169;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:969:"Ichthammol is obtained by sulfation and ammoniation of a distillate from mineral deposits (bituminous schists) originally found near Seefeld, Austria. It contains saturated and unsaturated hydrocarbons, nitrogenous bases, acids, and several thiophene derivs. Analysis shows at least 2.5% NH 3 and at least 10% S. It also contains traces of some 20 miner als and "zoomelanoidic" acids . Chemically, it is a sulfonated shale oil. It can be presented in two forms: pale sulfonated shale oil (PSSO), and dark sulfonated shale oil (DSSO). The last form is a thick reddish brown liquid, possessing a bituminous odor and taste. Pharmacologically, PSSO and DSSO have anti-inflammatory, bactericidal and fungicidal properties. Although the starting material for preparing this chemical is natural, Ichthammol itself is not natural (it is prepared synthetically). Furthermore, it is not a source for the natural parent(s). Ichthammol will not be considered as an NHP, but a drug.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76484";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:10:"Ichthammol";s:5:"title";s:10:"Ichthammol";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81169";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81170;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:327:"Maraviroc is an chemokine receptor antagonist drug developed by the drug company Pfizer that is designed to act against HIV by interfering with the interaction between HIV and CCR5. It is the first to enter Phase III clinical trials in the integrase inhibitor class. It targets integrase, an enzyme that HIV uses to integrate its genetic material into human cells. Raltegravir, and other integrase inhibitors, are often termed strand transfer inhibitors. This refers to the process of DNA strand transfer from the viral genome to the host genome. During 2006, the drug entered Phase III clinical trials, and it is available to certain patients with advanced HIV disease through an expanded access program. Raltegravir is a synthetic drug, not a NHP.                                                                                                         References:

There is preliminary evidence that it has a similar safety profile to caspofungin. It has proven efficacy against oesophageal candidiasis, but its main utility will probably be in invasive Candida infection; it will probably also have application in treating invasive Aspergillus infection. It is a member of the class of anti-fungal drugs known as the echinocandins. Anidulafungin is a synthetic material (not natural) and will not be considered as a NHP, but a drug.                             References:

The drug has been approved by the EMEA for use in the EU in 2006 and is today being sold in several European countries. Piracetam shares the same 2-oxo-pyrrolidone base structure with 2-oxo-pyrrolidine carboxylic acid (pyroglutamate). Piracetam is a cyclic derivative of GABA and one of the racetams. Piracetam was first synthesized in 1964 by scientists at the Belgian pharmaceutical company UCB. The drug was the first of the so-called nootropics ("smart drugs" or "cognitive enhancers"), that is, substances which purportedly enhance mental performance. Piracetam is a synthetic material (not natural) and will not be considered as a NHP, but a drug.                                              References:

[1] The Merck Index
[2] ChemID";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76495";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:11:"Neutral red";s:5:"title";s:11:"Neutral red";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81180";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81181;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:93:"A non-NHP because it is an antibiotic substance included in Schedule 2 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:116:"Un non PSN car une substance antibiotique comprise dans l'Annexe 2 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1267:"Daptomycin is a lipopeptide antibiotic used in the treatment of certain infections caused by Gram-positive organisms. It is a naturally-occurring compound found in the soil saprotroph Streptomyces roseosporus. The compound was originally discovered by researchers at Eli Lilly and Company in the 1980s. Daptomycin has been approved for the treatment of complicated skin and soft tissue infections. CUBICIN® (Daptomycin for Injection) is automathically excluded from NHPD because of the route of administration, i.e. injection. Furthermore, Cubicin is listed in 'Health Canada' as 'PRESCRIPTION PRODUCTS FOR HUMAN USE' in September 2007.  Due to its antibacteral activity (as antibiotic-antibiotics are excluded from the NHP Regulations by being listed in Schedule 2), despite its natural source, Daptomycin will not be considered as a NHP, but a drug. Both the acid and its sodium salt are used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and other rheumatic or musculoskeletal disorders, dysmenorrhea, and acute gout.  Naproxen and its salts are listed under Schedule F ingredients. The FDA approved the use of Naproxen sodium as an over-the-counter (OTC) drug in 1994. However, Naproxen is a synthetic material (not natural) and is not considered as a NHP, but a drug. [4] Sigma-Aldrich";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76497";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:8:"Naproxen";s:5:"title";s:8:"Naproxen";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81182";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81183;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:930:"Methyl hesperidin is the methylated form of Hesperidin. It has been used as a food additive.  In one study, in order to clarify the components of the commercial food additives, four main compounds from methylated hesperidin were isolated and identified as 3'-monomethylhesperidin, 3',5-dimethylhesperidin, 2',3,6'-trimethylhesperidin chalcone and 2',3,6'-trimethyl-4'-(rhamnosy1-2-O-methylglucosy1)-hesperetin chalcone, by spectroscopic analyses. These forms of methylated hesperidin are not naturally occurring substances and are not sources for Hesperidin.  Therefore, Methyl hesperidin will be considered as a drug, not NHP. NATRECOR® (Nesiritide) is a prescribed drug across the U.S. for the treatment of acutely decompensated congestive heart failure patients with dyspnea (shortness of breath) at rest or with minimal activity (such as talking, eating or bathing). Since drugs obtained by recombinant DNA procedures are listed under Schedule D to the Food and Drugs Act, Nesiritide will not be considered as a NHP, but a drug. The polyanion is readily soluble in water, and insoluble in lower alcohols. It may be prepared by polymerization or copolymerization of sodium styrene sulfonate or by sulfonation of polystyrene. It is used as a superplastifier in cement, crosslinked polystyrenes that are then sulfonated have found widespread use in ion-exchange applications, it is used as a dye improving agent for cotton and as proton exchange membranes in fuel cell applications. Commun. 103, 706 (1981)";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76504";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:9:"Teprenone";s:5:"title";s:9:"Teprenone";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81188";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81189;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1233:"Eosin is a red fluorescent dye. There are two very closely related compounds commonly referred to as eosin; Eosin Y and Eosin B. All eosins are bromine derivatives of fluorescein, used in dyeing textiles, ink manufacturing, in coloring cosmetics, in coloring gasoline and as a toner. The sodium or potassium salt of eosin, red to rose-colored crystalline powder, is used in biology to stain cells. Eosin is strongly absorbed by red blood cells, colouring them bright red. Eosin imparts reddish colour to cytoplasmic materials and connective tissues (cell membranes, extracellular structures) as a counterstain to haematoxylin and some Gram staining. Eosin B is water-soluble (distinctly bluish shade) and a cytoplasmic counterstain for hematoxylin. Eosins are prepared by bromination of Fluorescein (also a synthetic material). Eosins including Eosin B will not be considered as NHPs, but drugs. For its synthesis, the alkali cellulose (cellulose reacted with sodium hydroxide) is treated with chloromethane and propylene oxide.  Hypromellose is widely used as an excipient in oral and topical pharmaceutical formulations. [4] Handbook of Pharmaceutical Excipients, 5th Edition, By Raymond C Rowe et al. 2006";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76507";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:12:"Hypromellose";s:5:"title";s:12:"Hypromellose";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81191";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81192;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1750:"Carglumic acid is a structural analogue of N-Acetylglutamate [1,2], which is the naturally occurring activator of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase (CPS).  It is a N-carbamoyl derivative of Glutamic acid, recognized as an 'Orphan Drug' (a drug for rare diseases) in Europe [3].  Carglumic acid is used in the prevention and treatment of hyperammonemia encountered in liver diseases [4].  Unlike N-Acetylglutamate, Carglumic acid can enter the mitochondria [5].  Carglumic acid was shown to be weaker activator of CPS than N-Acetylglutamate, but in vivo it was more efficient [6].  A recent study shows oral Carglumic acid supplementation increases plasma arginine and somatotropin levels, leading to an increase in growth rate and muscle protein synthesis in nursing piglets [7].  These examples and many others show that the pharmacological properties (distribution, metabolism, excretion, mechanism of action, etc.) of Carglumic acid are different than N-Acetylglutamate and Glutamic acid.  Moreover, Carglumic acid is a synthetic material (not natural) and is not considered as a source for either Glutamic acid or N-Acetylglutamate.  Carglumic acid will not be considered as a NHP, but a drug. http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/bsc/vco/2007/00000005/00000001/art00004";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76512";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:10:"Maropitant";s:5:"title";s:10:"Maropitant";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81196";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81197;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1155:"p-Hydroxyephedrine (Methylsynephrine) has a similar structure to both Ephedrine and Synephrine (both are natural products); a hydroxyl group in para position on phenyl ring of Ephedrine and a methyl group in alpha position of Synephrine [1].  However, these groups (hydroxyl and methyl) can not be removed from the molecule by administration.  Therefore, it is not a source for Ephedrine and/or Synephrine.  p-Hydroxyephedrine has been used as an adrenergic [2].  As a stimulant, it is included in the world anti-doping prohibited list [3].  Synephrine is not included in this prohibited list.  Ephedrine (as stimulant) is included only if certain amount of it can be detected in urine sample.  Based on this information, Methylsynephrine should be considered different than Ephedrine and Synephrine.  As p-Hydroxyephedrine is not naturally occurring, it will not be considered as a NHP, but a drug. It is prepared by Pfizer under the brand name Sentrol.The preparation of Dirlotapide is achieved via a three-step linear synthesis [3]. When ingested by dogs, Dilotapide is metabolized to more than 20 metabolites[4]. Based on the complex synthetic pathway of this chemical, it’s metabolic pathway in vivo and the fact that there are only a few naturally occurring products that contain a C-F bond [5], this product is classified as a drug, not an NHP. It is synthesized from oxytetracycline or methacycline [2].  Oxytetracycline can be naturally occurring and was first found in the actinomycete (a group of gram-postive bacteria), Streptomyces rimosus, by Finlay [3].  Since Doxycycline is synthesized from oxytetracycline, is sometimes considered semi-synthetic in nature.  Doxycyline is found on Schedule F to the Food and Drugs Regulations when sold for intramuscular administration in caged birds.  And because it falls under Item 6 of Schedule 2 of the Natural Health Products Regulations (‘an antibiobiotic prepared from an alga, a bacterium, a fungus or a synthetic duplicate of that antibiotic’), it is considered as a non-NHP. du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1041:"Retapamulin (Fig.1) [1] is a topical antibiotic.  It is a semisynthetic pleuromutilin compound (via a 5-step synthetic process) [2][4] with in vitroactivity against gram-positive bacteria.  Pleuromutilin (Fig. 2) is a tricyclic, diterpene natural product first identified from the basidiomycete bacterial species Pleurotus mutilus (now referred to as Clitopilus scyphoides) [3] that possesses modest antibacterial activity against primarily gram-positive bacterial organisms.  Retapamulin falls under Item 6 of Schedule 2 of the Natural Health Products Regulations (an antibiotic prepared from an alga, a bacterium, a fungus or a synthetic duplicate of that antibiotic), it is considered as a non-NHP. It is synthesized from 3-bromo-5(trifluoromethyl)aniline (Fig. 2) through a 4-step process [2].  In vivo studies have shown that once ingested, biotransformations happens in the human body, which resulted in the detection of twenty distinct human metabolites [3].  Since this compound is synthetic, and contains a CF3 bond (which makes it unlikely that it can be naturally occuring) [4], and given the fact that it gets metabolized to more than 20 metabolites in the human body, it is considered a drug, not an NHP. Uranium nitrate, as Uranium nitricum, is one of the homeopathic medicines derived from Substances in Schedule C of the Food and Drugs Act (Radiopharmaceuticals); these substances are found in accepted pharmacopoeia (e.g. in this case in HPUS) but are not regulated under the regulations and therefore do not qualify for a DIN-HM. Uranium nitrate will not be considered as a NHP, but a schedule C substance. present in the adenohypophyseal tissue or the whole pituitary gland and can be used therapeutically as a lactation stimulating hormone, since this hormone is essential for the induction of lactation in mammals at parturition. Naltrexone is not included in Schedules I to V of the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act.  Methylnaltrexone bromide is a chiral molecule and the quaternary nitrogen molecule can be either in an R or S configuration.  However, it is not clear if the different isomers have different chemical and biological properties.  Methylnaltrexone bromide is synthesized from naltrexone by methylation of the tertiary nitrogen atom [4].  It is believed that the addition of this methyl group enhances the polarity and decreases the liposolubility of the molecule, thus making it difficult to cross the blood-brain barrier in humans (unlike naltrexone).  Based on these details, Methylnaltrexone bromide is considered as a non-NHP.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76599";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:24:"Methylnaltrexone bromide";s:5:"title";s:24:"Methylnaltrexone bromide";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81227";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81228;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:100:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations.";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1203:"Mircera [or continuous erythropoietin receptor activator (C.E.R.A.)] is marketed by Hoffmann-La Roche. It is a third-generation erythropoietic molecule created by integrating a large polymer chain into the molecule, thus increasing the molecular weight to twice that of epoetin at approximately 60 kDa. The methoxy-polyethylene glycol polymer chain is integrated via amide bonds between the N-terminal amino group or the e-amino group of lysine using a single succinimidyl butanoic acid linker. Mircera is an erythropoiesis-stimulating agent for the treatment of anemia [1]. Micera has been developed for the treatment of anaemia in patients with chronic kidney disease. Compared with other erythropoiesis-stimulating agents, C.E.R.A. has a unique pharmacological profile, including a longer elimination half-life and slower clearance rate [2]. Mircera showed clinical activity and safety in patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) [3] .Mircera was approved for use in Europe by the European Commission [4] and by the FDA [5]. The active ingredient in Mircera, i.e. Methoxy polyethylene glycol-epoetin beta, is a synthetic material (not natural) and will not be considered as a NHP, but a drug.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76600";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:40:"Methoxy polyethylene glycol-epoetin beta";s:5:"title";s:40:"Methoxy polyethylene glycol-epoetin beta";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81228";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81229;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:291:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations.Furthermore, as 6-Bromo-androst-1,4-diene-3,17-dione (both the alpha and beta isomers) is the brominated derivative of Androsta-1,4,6-triene-3,17-dione, hence this compound is also a non-NHP.";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:342:"Un non PSN parce que ce n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels. En outre, étant donné que le 6-bromo-androst-1,4-diène-3,17-dione (isomères alpha et bêta) est un dérivé bromé d'androstatriène-1,4,6 dione-3,17 ce premier est également considéré comme un non-PSN";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:2906:"Androsta-1,4,6-triene-3,17-dione (Fig. 1; also known as ATD) is one of the first inhibitors of aromatase, an enzyme responsible for the last step [conversion of androgens (such as androtenedione and testosterone) to estrogens, estradiol and estrone] in the transformations of cholesterol to the female sex hormones [1].  Consequently, this compound and other aromatase inhibitors are of interest in the treatment of estrogen-dependent breast cancers [2,3,4]. This  C19 3-Ketosteroid, which resemble the natural substrate of aromatase androstenedione, has been developed back in 1973 in a study initiated to determine the structural features of steroids in the inhibition of estrogen biosynthesis [5].  It is believed that the C(1)-C(2) double bond of this compound is one of the structural feature responsible for the inhibition of aromatase, demonstrated by the 'Suicide Substrate Inhibitor' mechanism of action hypothesis of aromatase [6].  Since,  a) no evidence have been found suggesting that ATD is naturally occurring, b) evidence found suggest that ATD is a synthetically prepared analog of the naturally occurring steroid androstenedione [5,7,8,9], and c) ATD cannot be considered as a source of androstenedione or other naturally occurring steroids based on its different pharmacological properties, ATD will not be considered as a NHP, but a drug.

This compound is an Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drug (NSAID) prodrug, as it is rapidly converted to its active metabolite Amfenac, a highly efficaceous NSAID [3]. Its prodrug nature have shown to be the reason of its superiority over other conventional NSAIDs, supported by in vivo pharmacokinetics and in vitro pharmacodynamics studies [4].  Indeed, Nepafenac has superior corneal permeability characteristics as a neutral drug, compared to other classial acidic NSAIDs.  It is believed that this faster penetration increases biodistribution and thus intraocular efficacy of its metabolite Amfenac [5].  This new and unique NSAID has been approved by the FDA in august 2005 for the treatment of pain and inflammation after cataract surgery [6], under the Alcon Laboratoried tradename Nevanac [7].  As Nepafenac [2,8] (and its acid Amfenac[9]) is a synthetically prepared compound, it will be considered as a drug, not a NHP.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76602";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:9:"Nepafenac";s:5:"title";s:9:"Nepafenac";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81230";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81231;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:767:"Potassium peroxymonosulfuric acid is the potassium salt of Peroxymonosulfuric acid [1]. It is used as an oxidizing agent [2]. Potassium peroxymonosulfuric acid is a component of a triple salt with the formula 2KHSO5·KHSO4·K2SO4 [3-4] which is widely used in synthesis (chemistry). Peroxymonosulfuric acid and its salts, including Potassium salt, are synthetic compounds (not natural) and are not sources for any natural products (although salts are potential source for the minerals such as Potassium). Potassium peroxymonosulfuric acid will not be considered as a NHP, but a drug.

It is a mild, general oxidizing agent which is a suitable replacement for peroxycarboxylic acids [2]. It can be used to carry out a wide variety of oxidation reactions [3]. Magnesium monoperoxyphthalate is a synthetic compound [4] . Although is is a potential source of Magnesium, the main action, which is its oxidizing property, excludes it from being a source of a natural product. Magnesium monoperoxyphthalate will not be considered as a NHP, but a drug.

It is a synthetic compound which can be obtained for example by the action of hydrogen peoxide on acetic acid (or acetic anhydride) in presence of sulfuric acid as catalyst [2]. Peracetic acid is not natural and not a direct source of any natural product; its main action, as oxidizing agent, excludes it from being a source of a natural product such as acetic acid or hydrogen peroxide. Peracetic acid will not be considered as a NHP, but a drug.

[4] www.basilea.com/template_loader.php?tplpage_id=160";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"76680";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:12:"Ceftobiprole";s:5:"title";s:12:"Ceftobiprole";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81235";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81236;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1357:"Romiplostim is a recombinant protein, known as a peptibody, made up of two disulfide-bonded IgG1 heavy-chain and kappa light-chain constant regions (fragment crystallizable [Fc] fragments), each of which is covalently bound at residue 228 of the heavy chain with two identical peptide sequences linked via polyglycine [1].   Nplate (trade name by Amgen) is indicated for the treatment of thrombocytopenia in adult patients with chronic immune (idiopathic) thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) who have had an insufficient response to corticosteroids, immunoglobulins or splenectomy.  It binds to and activates the human thrombopoietin receptor despite having no sequence homology with human thrombopoietin [2].  Although the details concerning the production of this protein is not available, it is known to be expressed in E. coli [1].  Because this protein is not naturally occurring, and presumably produced via recombinant DNA procedure (as it is described as a recombinant protein), Romiplostim will be considered as a drug.

Procaine is rapidly and almost completely hydrolyzed by plasma pseudocholinesterae to p-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) and diethylaminoethanol. Procaine is used for infiltration anesthesia and for peripheral or sympathetic nerve block and spinal anesthesia. It is also used in dentistry for infiltration anesthesia or nerve block. However, it has little topical activity [3]. Procaine is a synthetic material discovered by German scientist Einhorn in early 20th century [4]. It is not naturally occurring and is not used as a source for PABA. Procaine will not be considered as a NHP but a drug.

Hexetidine is a synthetic material (not found in nature) and is not a source of any natural product. Hexetidine will not be considered as a NHP, but a drug.

It is a reddish-yellow gas which can be prepared from chlorine and sodium chlorite, from potassium chlorate and sulfuric acid, by passing NO2 through a column of sodium chlorate, etc. [1]. It is equal or superior to chlorine when used as waste water disinfectant [2]. It has been used in bleaching cellulose, paper-pulp, flour, leather, fats and oils, textiles, beeswax; purification of water; taste and odor control of water; cleaning and detanning leather; manuf of chlorite salts; oxidizing agent; bactericide, antiseptic and deodorizer [1]. Chlorine dioxide is not naturally occuring substance and will not be considered as a NHP, but a drug.

Tromethamine is a synthetic material (not natural) and is not used as a source for any natural product. Tromethamine will not be considered as a NHP, but a drug.

This compound is absorbed rapidly (with 60-80% bioavailability after oral administration); its pharmacokinetics is dose-dependent with peak plasma concentrations occurring 2.5-4 hours after administration (about 90% is bound to plasma proteins); and about 30% is excreted unchanged in the urine with the rest being fecal eliminated or metabolized in the liver [3].  As this compound is synthetically prepared [4] and not found in nature, it will be considered as a drug.";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"77418";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:11:"Rivaroxaban";s:5:"title";s:11:"Rivaroxaban";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81241";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81242;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1450:"Melamine is a synthetic material, a trimer of cyanamide, that can be prepared by heating of dicyandiamide under pressure, or using urea [1]. Most melamine is reacted with formaldehyde to produce resins for laminating and adhesive applications. One of the major uses of melamine is in the upper sheet of laminated counter- and tabletops. Another important use of melamine is as the amino cross-linker in heat-cured paint systems. Other uses include the preparation of wet-strength resins for paper, water clarifying resins, ion-exchange resins, plastic molding compounds, adhesives, fire retardants in polyurethane foams, and intumescent paints. Important new applications are under development in the field of fire retardants for polymeric materials, especially polyurethane foams [2-3]. Pathological evaluation of cats and dogs that had died from the acute renal failure indicated the presence of crystals (a melamine-cyanuric acid complex - as a proposed form) in kidney tubules [4]. Melamine is not naturally occuring and will not be considered as a NHP.

This product is synthesized from picolinic acid and vanadyl sulphate (VS) which is less toxic than vanadate [2].
Studies in rats have demonstrated that after administration, some the vanadium complex  remained unchanged in the liver and kidney, and the slow elimination of the picolinate complex from the circulation blood of rats was attributed to its interaction with blood components [3]
Based on the above facts, Bis(picolinato)oxovanadium(IV) [VO(pic)2] is not considered as an NHP, nor as a source of an NHP.Reference:

[1] Journal of Inorganic biochemistry, Volume 77, Number 3, 30 November 1999 , pp. 215-224(10)

[3] Journal of  Inorganic biochemistry, Volume 91, 2002, pp 327-338";s:16:"field_legacy_nid";s:5:"77421";s:14:"field_workflow";s:9:"Published";s:30:"field_approved_ingredient_name";s:38:"Bis(picolinato)oxovanadium(IV) complex";s:5:"title";s:38:"Bis(picolinato)oxovanadium(IV) complex";s:3:"nid";s:5:"81244";s:7:"changed";s:10:"2013-10-16";s:14:"workflow_state";s:9:"Published";}i:81245;a:12:{s:4:"body";s:0:"";s:21:"field_ingredient_role";s:2:"NN";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_e";s:99:"A non-NHP because not a naturally occurring substance included in Schedule 1 of the NHP Regulations";s:25:"field_non_nhp_rationale_f";s:129:"Un non PSN parce que n'est pas une substance naturelle comprise dans l'Annexe 1 du Règlement sur les produits de santé naturels";s:19:"field_old_rationale";s:1289:"3-7-bis-(2-hydroxyethyl)-icaritin is a recently made synthetic derivative of icariin and icaritin (natural products [1]). In its synthesis, 2 sugars in icariin replaced by hydroxyethyl group. This modification was performed to improve the inhibitoty activity of icariin against phosphodiesterase-5A1 (PDE5A1). Results showed that 3-7-bis-(2-hydroxyethyl)-icaritin was 80 times more potent than icariin, and its selectivity versus phosphodiesterase-6 (PDE6) and cyclic adenosine monophosphate-phosphodiesterase (cAMP-PDE) was much higher in comparison with sildenafil (viagra- used in treatment of male impotence). The improved pharmacodynamic profile and lack of cytotoxicity on human fibroblasts [2] proved that there is a significant difference between 3-7-bis-(2-hydroxyethyl)-icaritin and icariin (and even icaritin which is 3 times more potent than icariin). 3-7-bis-(2-hydroxyethyl)-icaritin as a synthetic compound which is not used as a source of icariin or icaritin, with signicant differences in pharmacological properties with icaritin, will not be considered as a NHP, but a drug.

naturally in many plants, Figure 2) [1][2]. The formation of quercetin chalcone is described in patent # 5,997,184[3].  The addition of the phenolic hydroxy group increases the hydrophilicity effect, and accounts for the greater absorption and bioavailibility of Quercetin chalcone, compared to the parent molecule.
